subject: Julie Chen: In Deepest Sympathy
body:
CBSNews.com












  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






April 24, 
      2007
 
Hi, 
      everybody,
 
My heart goes out 
      to the families of the nine U.S. soldiers killed in 
      Baghdad today after a 
      suicide bomber struck. An 
      al Qaeda-linked group claims responsibility for the 
      attack on the patrol base north of Baghdad. Check CBSNews.com 
      for the latest on that story. 
 
Also, 
      my condolences go out to the wife of journalist-turned-historian 
      David Halberstam. He was a true gentleman 
      and such a great writer. I remember reading his book "The Powers that Be" 
      in my freshman year of journalism school. It was one of the many books on 
      our required reading list. It gave me a firm understanding of what a 
      powerful medium television is and how the media truly do help shape both 
      public policy and public opinion. Years later and not too long ago (within 
      the last three years), I got to meet him, and hesitated to tell him the 
      influence his book had on me as a teenager. I now regret not telling him 
      when the opportunity presented itself.
 
On a lighter note, 
      we are enjoying another great spring day here in 
      New York 
      City, perfect weather 
      for tonight's sixth annual Tribeca 
      Film Festival. Over the years it has grown from a small event trying 
      to revitalize the Tribeca neighborhood following the tragic events of 
      Sept. 11, to a highly-regarded annual celebration of wonderful works in 
      the film industry. Then again, with the talents of Robert De Niro supporting such a cause, how could 
      it miss?
 
It was 
      also the perfect weather to spend time on the Plaza with our friend Kris 
      Connell from Real Simple magazine, who showed us some practical double uses for ordinary household items. 
      My favorite of the day is using a flat iron, normally sold for use on your 
      hair, to press those hard-to-reach spots between buttons on a collared 
      shirt.
 
We 
      also continued our "Wedding in a Week" series, and today, we 
      saw bridal party fashions. It'll be tough for our bride Lisa to pick 
      her wedding gown for the big day. She looked beautiful in all of 
      them. We wish the happy couple the best in their life together as one. 
      Tomorrow, Lisa and her fiancé Stephen will look at wedding flowers. 
      
 
Tomorrow on the show, are you a "fan"jaya? American Idol finalist 
      Sanjaya Malakar will be here to talk about 
      what really went on behind the scenes, and we'll see who People magazine's 
      most beautiful people are.
 
Take 
      care,

Julie 
      ChenEarlyShow@cbs.com
